back—I saw the prisoner every time I went—I took it when the hands stopped, and when the glass fell out, and he said he would have the glass ground in—I saw him five or six times—I said if it did not go better, I should have it exchanged, and he did ultimately change it—he lent me a silver one to take home—he was to get some open faced watches and some hunting watches for me to look at—he had only got a hunting watch—I was not satisfied—he said he would bring me some—he let me have a gold one, with a silver dial, to show my husband—on 10th Oct. the prisoner brought two open faced ones—my husband proposed my having the one with silver figures, and the prisoner would have to return me 10s. 6d.—he took all the four watches away with him—he brought two, and two I had in the house; he said he must take them all back—on Friday, the 13th, the prisoner came, and said the silver one had failed, he had found it twenty minutes too slow—my husband said, "Let her have the gold one with the silver dial"—he said he would let me have it the following week and the day after that he cut his throat.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. How long had you any one watch in your possession? A. About six weeks; from 16th Aug. till 29th Sept.—I had no thought of exchanging it.

JOHN CARTER, ESQ The prisoner was in my service—it was his duty to manage the shop in Tooley-street—it was his duty to keep books of the transactions in that shop—if a customer bought a watch he should enter it—this is the book which he kept—here is no entry in it, from 16th Aug. till 29th Sept., of any watch sold to Horspool, or to any one else, for 4l. 14s. 6d.—I have carefully looked through the book—he has never accounted to me for that 4l. 14s. 6d.—having received a communication, I went to the prisoner on 14th Oct., and charged him with robbery and embezzlement—I had heard he was in difficulties—I upbraided him with his conduct, and told him I should feel it my duty to give him into custody—he begged me not to do so—I reminded him that this was not the first time he had been in difficulties—he left the room, went up stairs, locked himself in his bed room, and cut his throat.

Cross-examined. Q. Why was not this stated before to the officer, or to any one else, that you had made a statement to him about his previous difficulties? A. I stated it to the prisoner, and told the servant to fetch a policeman, and the prisoner instantly went up stairs and cut his throat—I have occasionally been absent from that place for a month, but I believe not since he has been with me—it was not his duty to account to me whenever I went there, but whenever I chose to ask him—I might be away a fort-night, it was rarely three weeks—I had the fullest confidence in him, and thought my property was safe in his hands—I have been to him since 16th Aug.—it might be once a week—I was there perhaps two or three times in the month—the books will tell the sums I have received from him—I judge, because I do not see the entry in this book, that the money has not been paid—on some occasions money has been offered to me by him, and I said it was not convenient to take it—I believe on the evening before there was a balance of as much as 20l., which I did not take.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. On the evening before, did you enter into an account with him? A. I had occasion to suspect him the day before, and I saw him on the night of the 13th—I did not enter into an account with him—I was engaged with the stock.
EDMUND WALKER (policeman, M 274). On 14th Oct. I was called to take the prisoner—I saw the Alderman in the shop—I went up stairs and broke

the door open—I found the prisoner on the bed with his throat cut—I got a surgeon, and took him to the hospital—a fortnight afterwards I 'told him he was charged with robbery and embezzlement—he stated that he did not care if Alderman Carter gave him seven years, so long as he behaved well to his wife.

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Month.

128.
ANN KELLY,
FRANCES M'ENOFF , and
JOHN M'ENOFF
, feloniously cutting and wounding
William Cain, on his face, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

WILLIAM CAIN . I live in Maypole-alley, High-street, Southwark; I am a bell hanger. On Wednesday evening, 15th Nov., between 6 and 7 o'clock, I went into M'Enoff's house, which is opposite to mine—I there saw my cousin Kelly, and Frances M'Enoff, and John M'Enoff—I was given in charge for a deserter, but I found it out, and I went into their house, and I said to John M'Enoff, that he was b—deceitful for informing against me—Kelly was cleaning some knives—she had some knives in her hand, and I suppose she thought I came in for a row—she up with a knife, and stabbed me in the lip—the husband of the young woman put his hand round me to hold me, and Frances struck me in the head with a knife; that wound bled—I do not know; I suppose he was trying to take his wife away—he struck me several times with a soldering iron, made out of a penny piece—he was trying to keep his wife and daughter away—I do not wish to press the charge against him.

Q. Was that all that happened? A. Yes; he struck me with the sol
dering iron about the arms, but only I dare say to keep away his wife; I tried to get away—I went down stairs and hallooed out, "Murder!"—I cannot recollect in what state I was, when I came down—I was taken to the hospital—I cannot tell how long I was there; I ran away, and got them out of gaol in the morning—this is the man that has got a family of children, and never had a key turned on him—I am a soldier and have got to go to fight the Russians, and if you will let us shake hands and make it up I will go and fight the Russians—would I have the curse of a family of children in my breast?—this is not the wound they gave me in my face—I hit that against the bed post since.
NOT GUILTY .

129.
GEORGE BURNAND
, stealing 1 watch, value 10s.; the goods of
Mary Curtis; also, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Charles Irving, and stealing 1 handkerchief, and other goods, value 4s.; his property; and 1 handkerchief, and other goods, value 15s. 6d.; the goods of Mary Curtis: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

130.
JOHN HENRY LYNN
, embezzling 34l., 32l., and 33l.; also, 49l. 10s., 26l. 7s., and 87l. 10s. 9d.; the moneys of
John Robert Tassett Burnett, and others, his masters: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

131.
FRANCIS BORTHWICK
, feloniously marrying
Emma Jordan, his wife Jane being alive: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Twelve Months.

132.
MARY MACKMANN
, stealing 1 cart, and 1 gelding; the pro
perty of
Samuel John Sewell: to which she

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Year.

133.
JOHN MARSHALL was indicted
for b—y.

GUILTY. of an attempt. Aged 30.—
Confined Two Years.

134.
CHARLES BROWN
, feloniously killing and slaying
Charles Nelson; he was also charged upon the Coroner's Inquisition with the like offence.

ELLEN WILSON . I live at No. 31, St. George's New-town, Southwark. On Monday, 30th Oct. I was in company with Elizabeth Hazle at a public house—I don't know the sign of it—the prisoner and Nelson came in, and we afterwards went together to another public house—there was some quarrelling there—we took a cab from there—there were five of us got in; the prisoner, Nelson, my companion Elizabeth Hazle, a man I knew as an Irishman, and myself—we drove into Mint-street, where Hazle lived—we had some drink there, and they quarreled again—the Irishman and Nelson were quarrelling first—Nelson then called Brown a son of a b—, and told him that he was no mate not to take his part—I believe they were ship
mates—Nelson then caught hold of the prisoner by the collar or handker
chief, until he was nearly black in the face—upon that I ran for the police—I left the Irishman and the two men in the room—when I came back I heard an Irish girl who lived in the next room, Mary Ready, halloo out that he was stabbed—I went into the room and saw Nelson lying dead on the ground; he was bleeding—there was only Brown, Nelson, and the Irishman in the room—the deceased was lying on his side and a dagger was sticking in his neck; I pulled it out and put it in my pocket, and afterwards gave it to the policeman—when I left the room I left Brown on the bed nearly strangled by the deceased—I can't say that the Irishman was drunk, but Nelson and Brown were very much in liquor.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You are an unfortunate female, I believe? A. Yes—the two mates were very drunk at the public house—they had very little at our place—I think the deceased was more in fault—he first began the row with the Irishman at the public house—he afterwards called the prisoner a son of a b—, because he did not join in the row with the Irishman—he called him that twice—the prisoner offered no violence to the deceased at the public house—I do not know whether they had just come from the same vessel—after they got to Hazle's place, the Irishman and the deceased still kept quarrelling and calling one another bad names—the prisoner and deceased were very much in liquor indeed—the deceased at last seized Brown, and threw him down, and hit him several times with a cane—Brown had not done anything to him then—he had caught hold of Nelson in the cab, and told him to be quiet, and not quarrel—we had only been to two public houses—we were in company about half an hour—after they got to our place Nelson kept sparring at Brown, and calling him names—before I went for the police Brown was black in the face—I told Nelson if he did not let the man go I would go for a constable, and he said he did not care one God d—n—he had got Brown on the bed, and was upon him, holding him by the handkerchief—I left him on the bed when I went for the police—as far as I saw, the violence was on the part of Nelson towards Brown, and not of Brown towards Nelson.

MARY ANN RUSSELL . I went into Hazle's room on 30th Oct., between 3 and 4 o'clock—I saw the man, Nelson, on the floor, and the prisoner holding him by the hair of his head with his left hand, and a dagger in his right hand—I tapped him on the shoulder, and said, "Bridle your temper, and don't spill blood on a shipmate"—he did not say anything—Nelson was then lying on his back, with his head against the door—I saw blood upon him—I tapped him on the shoulder, and said, "Mate, you are stabbed," and found that my hand was covered with blood—I saw a wound in his neck—I did not see any weapon in the neck—the prisoner had it in his hand—I saw no blow struck—fie was bleeding from the neck—I went down stairs, and met sergeant Davis at the door of the house—I saw no weapon used.

Cross-examined. Q. You went before the Coroner? A. Yes—I was before the Magistrate, but was not examined—both the prisoner and deceased were very drunk indeed—I do not think the prisoner knew what he was doing, for he was very much excited in drink-—he never spoke a word—I had never seen them before.

MARY READY . I live at No. 3, Harrow-street, Southwark, in the same house as Hazle. On 30th Oct., I saw the prisoner and two other men there—I did not notice them when they came in, but I saw afterwards that they were drunk—I saw them standing up against the mantel-piece, and I thought they were fighting—I heard the deceased say to the prisoner, "You son of a b—;" (that was after Hazle was gone)—he said he was no son of a b—; he said, "I will fight you; I will fight the best of the two, but don't let the two of you come on me together"—I saw the deceased come up and hit him with his right hand in the left breast, and knocked him on the ground—the deceased afterwards stooped down to hit him in the face, and the prisoner caught hold of him with his right hand and said, "Don't hit me while I am down," he then pulled a dagger out of his left hand pocket, and stabbed him in the neck—I only saw him do it once—I then ran into my own room, rose up the window, and screamed out "Murder!" and "Police!"
Cross-examined. Q. Was the deceased using the prisoner with great violence? A. Yes; and calling him very bad names—he hit him three times before he chucked him up against the bed.

WILLIAM DAVIS (police-sergeant, M 15). I was called to the house, and saw the deceased and prisoner there—they were both very drunk—the deceased was bleeding—I asked him what was the matter—he said to Brown, "You should not have stabbed me"—Brown said, "You struck me first"—he said, "I know I struck you first, but you should not have used the knife," or, "dagger"—Wilson gave me this dagger in the prisoner's presence, and said, "This is what he done it with, policeman"—the deceased gave the name of Charles Nelson—when I first went into the room, I found the prisoner and deceased there, and another man was coming down the stairs.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you in the habit of seeing many of these mari
ners? A. Not particularly; I have seen some of them carry a weapon similar to this—it is a dagger, sharp at both sides—they generally carry a knife with a string; and sometimes carry these things at their side.

WILLIM TIMEWELL (police-sergeant, M 6). I was at the station when the prisoner was brought there—he was very drunk—I read over the charge to him, but he did not seem to understand it—afterwards when he became sober, I called him out from the cell, took him into a room by himself, and read over the charge to him, and he appeared very much surprised—he said, "I know no more about stabbing him than a child born this day."
Cross-examined. Q. Did he say they were shipmates together? A. He did; he said what he had done, he had done in his own defence; but he did not know whether he had stabbed him or not.

JOHN FLINT SOUTH . I am senior surgeon of St. Thomas's Hospital. The deceased was brought there, between 4 and 5 o'clock, on 30th Oct.—he was then very drunk—I examined him, and found a wound on the left side of the nape of the neck, about one inch long; a wound on the back of the blade bone, on the left side of the spine, which was the important wound; a deep wound in the left loin; a superficial skin wound on the outside of the left knee, and two other superficial wounds—he died from wound of the lung—the wound between the spine and blade bone penetrated the lung—I found that afterwards, on a post mortem examination—I have no doubt that was the cause of death—it is very probable that that wound might have been inflicted by a person lying below him, by striking round him over the shoulder—this dagger might produce such a wound.
Cross-examined. Q. The other wounds were not necessarily mortal? A. No—the penetration of the lung, produced collapse of the lung, and caused—death.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury, an account of the great provocation he received.—
Confined One Month Solitary.
